item.title: Gideon the Ninth
item.description: WOULD HAVE HARROWHARK’S BABIES. I mean, it’s a good thing I like nice people in real life, because in fiction, Harrowhark is 10000% my type.

item.title: Inferno
item.description: So good to read this while steeped in Florentine history. These are real people and real places, not just an abstract Lewis-esque allegory.

item.title: Parable of the Sower
item.description: I loved the Earthseed parts of this (God is Change), but the dystopia parts went the way of most dystopias for me, almost too limited in its imagination?

item.title: Shadow & Claw
item.description: I think a series that has its own [[books/lexicon urthus|lexicon]] counts for the ultimate feat of [[notes/puzzle-book worldbuilding|puzzle-book worldbuilding]].

item.title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi
item.description: A rollicking pirate adventure AND an extensive bibliography for the historical accuracies! Be still my heart! This was brilliant. It would be easier to make a list of the things I didn’t like about it than all the things I loved.

item.title: The Curse of Chalion
item.description: It’s been easier lately for me to review the books I don’t like than the ones I do, because the ones I do, it’s just love, love, love.

item.title: Too Like the Lightning
item.description: Of course I’m immediately starting all over again after [[books/perhaps the stars|Perhaps The Stars]]. Every time, tingling chills down my spine on page 254:

item.title: Seven Surrenders
item.description: There’s no way I can talk comprehensively about this series, so for now I’m just going to keep a running list of different things I notice each time I read them.

item.title: Harrow the Ninth
item.description: Amount of times this book made me cry: [redacted]. It is a sum equal to or only slightly less than the amount of times it made me cackle, gasp, and yelp.

item.title: Paladin of Souls
item.description: Magnificent. I didn’t think Bujold could top Cazaril as a character, and she does. Illvin and beloved Ista. Such a rich, full, scarred world she’s created.

item.title: Purgatorio
item.description: Reading this alongside Guido Ruggiero’s [[books/the renaissance in italy|The Renaissance in Italy]] is A+ recommended. Once again, vastly more interesting than my first exposure, where school curriculum wanted it read like it was Pilgrim’s Progress.

item.title: Sword & Citadel
item.description: Ugh, my [[notes/puzzle-book worldbuilding|puzzle-loving brain]] absolutely loved this. Even all the places where it was like, Gene, your Roman Catholicism is showing.

item.title: Nona the Ninth
item.description: Verdict still stands after book three: would have Harrowhark’s babies. The end of [[books/gideon the ninth|Gideon]] had some pacing things, the start of [[books/harrow the ninth|Harrow]] had some pacing things; Nona was the one I barreled through in 1.

item.title: Paradiso
item.description: My dilemma since the early years of Sunday school: hell is more interesting than paradise. Thus, true to form, though I wanted to be contrary, [[books/inferno|Inferno]] is more interesting than any amount of heavenly light (so bright!

item.title: The Hallowed Hunt
item.description: Not the heights of Ista or Cazaril, but going backwards in this timeline instead of forwards is a choice I admire.

item.title: The Will to Battle
item.description: Reader, I cried like Mycroft Canner. It’s very much the first half of a whole (third quarter of four?), and it needs [[books/perhaps the stars|the last book]] to be complete, but what a feat it is on its own.

item.title: Perhaps the Stars
item.description: I still haven’t found the words to talk about this one. Maybe next year I will. It should be in the Smithsonian, or win the Nobel prize, or something, as one of humanity’s greatest achievements.

item.title: William Blake: The Complete Illuminated Books
item.description: Reading Blake, I always get the sense he’s working in a fever, trying to translate an ecstatic vision for us mortals.

item.title: Always Coming Home
item.description: I’ve been saving this one because [[notes/the carrier bag theory of fiction|the Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction]] has been such a foundational text for me, and this is where Ursula, more than ever, puts that theory to practice.

item.title: Conversion
item.description: A 12th century missionary finds shelter in a blizzard with a gruff, kindhearted hermit. The conversion is his own, shedding the self-loathing shame for genuine tender romantic connection.

item.title: Exodus 20
item.description: If you’re gonna write monster kink, make it a biblically accurate angel. And throw in some searing social/political/theological commentary. This was excellent.

item.title: Lent
item.description: It seems like every year there’s a book that I want to beg people to read because I struggle to describe it, and it’s nothing like what they’d expect.

item.title: Tao Te Ching
item.description: In my opinion, the definitive text. The Ursula K. Le Guin translation (and footnotes!) is everything. Nobody listens to language the way Ursula does.

item.title: Tao Te Ching: A New English Version
item.description: Since I had [[books/tao te ching|Ursula K. Le Guin’s translation]] on hand, I picked up Stephen Mitchell’s as well. Reading them side by side: Mitchell’s version is what we expect spiritual texts to be; Le Guin’s is what spiritual texts should be.

item.title: The Cyclist and His Shadow
item.description: I like how right away, in the forward, Thomazeau François is pitting this book against [[books/the rider|The Rider]] as the seminal classic of cycling literature.

item.title: The Saint of Bright Doors
item.description: Gobsmacked at how good this is, without even the caveat of “for a first novel.” Fetter, the feral only child of a messiah, trained by his mother as assassin, destined to commit matricide and fratricide, navigates a dystopian Sri Lanka far too recognizable in the present.

item.title: The Second Safest Mountain
item.description: What even is Otava Heikkilä’s brain? There are nuns and orgies and authoritarian patriarchal tentacle gods, and it maps completely onto the experience of being outcast in our world, for simply being true to yourself.

item.title: The Twice-Drowned Saint
item.description: I don’t even know how the hell to describe this, except amazing. Apparently my unintentional theme lately is biblically accurate angels—see [[books/pet|Pet]], see [[books/exodus 20|Freydís Moon]].
